The results in the ALife paper compare novelty search to both fitness-based=
 search and random search in a maze navigation domain. On a moderately-dece=
ptive map, novelty search outperforms fitness search, and fitness search ou=
tperforms random search. On a very deceptive map, novelty search once again=
 outperforms the other two methods, but fitness-based search is approximate=
ly equivalent to a random search.

Any form random search (such as the one =
you suggest) does not exploit any sort of domain information and will likel=
y perform very badly at almost any task if a large proportion of genotypes =
specify degenerate behaviors (which is likely the case for real-world domai=
ns; most random genomes likely encode no useful information).

To understan=
d why a search for behavioral novelty may often be much different than a ra=
ndom search of the genotype space, it is helpful to consider the mapping of=
 a genotype to a behavior. This mapping is a composition of the mapping bet=
ween genotype to phenotype and from phenotype to behavior space. 

The firs=
t mapping (from genotype to phenotype) is the encoding. In neuroevolution, =
this encoding translates the genotype to a neural network. NEAT and HyperNE=
AT are two potential encodings among many.

The second mapping (from phenot=
ype to behavior space) maps a neural network to its behavior when evaluated=
 in a domain (for example, the coordinate within the maze where a navigatio=
nal robot with a particular brain would navigate to). 

It is important to =
note that for many encodings (including NEAT and HyperNEAT), the space of g=
enotypes is effectively infinite-dimensional because of genetic operators t=
hat add genes. This allows NEAT to evolve ANNs of arbitrary complexity and =
HyperNEAT to evolve CPPNs of arbitrary complexity. 

However, the space of =
behaviors is typically not infinite-dimensional; for example, in the maze d=
omain, it is only two-dimensional. So, the space of behaviors may be signif=
icantly smaller than the space of all possible neural networks. 

It is als=
o somewhat reasonable to believe that perturbing a genotype that maps to a =
certain behavior may often generate a similar, yet slightly different behav=
ior. In this way, it may be more effective to explore the behavior space by=
 perturbing genotypes representing novel behaviors rather than exhaustively=
 or randomly searching through the underlying genotype space.

Imagine a si=
tuation in which 99% of all genomes map to degenerate behaviors that do not=
hing, but the remaining 1% of genomes map to behaviors that are functional,=
 and these 1% of genomes form a connected mesh in the search space (that is=
, they are reachable from each other through mutations). In a random search=
, 99% of all evaluations will be wasted, while a search for novelty will ex=
ploit domain information to more effectively find these non-degenerate beha=
viors.

In summary, random search ignores domain information, while a searc=
h for novelty (or a fitness-based search) does utilize domain information.
